haefeleuser wrote:

> I posted this question half a year ago. The answer that I received
> was to use a decorator. It works this way. But I cannot execute a
> test with its decorator in Eclipse. So I cannot use it.

I strongly disagree. Certainly you can. Read on.

> I've coded something like this in the main method to solve the
> problem:
> TestDecorator myTestSetup = new MyTestSetup(new SupplierArticleTest
> ("testInitialValidation"));
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(myTestSetup);

What you're doing here defeats the purpose of one-time setup/teardown. 
Usually, one does this:

public class DecoratedTestSuite {
     public static Test suite() {
         return new MyTestSetup(new TestSuite(TestCaseToDecorate.class));
     }
}

Now MyTestSetup.setUp() executes, then all the tests in 
TestCaseToDecorator, followed at last by MyTestSetup.tearDown(). Is this 
what you want?

If so, then you should be able to right-click DecoratedTestSuite in 
Eclipse and run it as JUnit tests, because it has a suite() method.

<pause />

I just tried it, and it works.

> The most straightforward thing would have been if I had two
> additional methods in the TestCase: setUpTestCase() and
> tearDownTestCase(). Both would be called only once, the first, when
> the test (all test methods in a TestCase) starts and the last when
> the test ends (all test methods in a TestCase).

That's exactly what TestSetup already does, so there's no need to add 
that behavior to TestCase.
